post_text: Parents and Guardians- As was discussed at our parent meetings last week, the biggest challenges to the return to school are the significant requirements placed on parents if a student is sent home for a temperature above 100 degrees or displaying any over Covid-19 symptoms. In order for any student to return to school after a temperature or displaying other symptoms, they MUST have a Dr.'s note clearing them to return AND a negative Covid-19 test result. Both must be presented to the school nurse in order for the student to return to school. These requirements have been put in place by the NYS Department of Health. We hope these requirements will be 'relaxed' before school starts but parents should be aware of them as they make their return to school plans. Any questions, please contact Mr. Bower directly in the District Office at #569-5200 ext 5240. Thank you.

Budget vote 20-21: All school districts in NYS are required to hold our annual budget vote using absentee ballots due to Executive Order 202.26 from Governor Cuomo. No in-person voting is allowed. That being said, be sure to follow all directions for an absentee ballot to make sure it can be counted. Here is some info on that process:
1. Remember to fill out the front of the Oath envelope and sign the back of it when returning your ballot.

2. We are hearing from people that are leery about filling out the front with their name/address because of privacy. That information is only used to verify names on the registered voter list. It is NOT used to tally how people voted. Once the envelope is opened on June 9th and the four ballots put in individual piles, there is no way to determine how any individual person voted.

Thank you to the almost 300 people that have already returned a ballot!

Looking for a fun family activity over break? Head over to the Curtiss Museum and check out our 2nd Grade Community Collaboration Project!

Miss Paas' 2nd grade artists learned about what it means to collaborate respectfully with other artists. They also learned about the importance of displaying your artwork out in the community to share with others. Using various materials of their choice, students created an artwork of their own house and a place in the community that they visit. Then, we had a day to assemble the artwork onto one large paper, as a whole class.

Besides visiting our artists' beautiful work, the museum has family activities going on over break. We are so proud of our artists' hard work and all of the learning they have been doing in the art room. So, come check it out and support both the Curtiss Museum and our Glenn Curtiss Elementary School art program!
